title: Lewis-Syford House
text: The Lewis-Syford House is a historic house on the campus of the <a href="University%20of%20Nebraska%E2%80%93Lincoln">University of Nebraska–Lincoln</a> in <a href="Lincoln%2C%20Nebraska">Lincoln, Nebraska</a>. It was built in 1878 for Reverend Elisha M. Lewis, a Presbyterian missionary who had been a chaplain in the <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, and designed in the <a href="Second%20Empire%20architecture">Second Empire style</a>. It was bequeathed by Constance C. Syford to the <a href="Nebraska%20State%20Historical%20Society">Nebraska State Historical Society</a> in 1965. It is the oldest building on the UNL campus. It has been listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places%20listings%20in%20Lancaster%20County%2C%20Nebraska">National Register of Historic Places</a> since February 18, 1971.
